dt: {bc}to change from good to bad in morals, manners, or actions
{bc}to degrade with unsound principles or moral values

dt.t: Some fear the merger will {wi}corrupt{/wi} the competitive marketplace.
The fruits were transported without being {wi}corrupted{/wi}.

dt: {bc}to alter from the original or {a_link|correct} form or version

dt.t: leaving the bodies to {wi}corrupt{/wi} on the field

pt: {sc}debase{/sc} {sc}vitiate{/sc} {sc}deprave{/sc} {sc}corrupt{/sc} {sc}debauch{/sc} {sc}pervert{/sc} mean to cause deterioration or lowering in quality or character. {sc}debase{/sc} implies a loss of position, worth, value, or dignity.
{sc}vitiate{/sc} implies a destruction of purity, validity, or effectiveness by allowing entrance of a fault or defect.
{sc}deprave{/sc} implies moral deterioration by evil thoughts or influences.

pt.t: the claim that society is {it}depraved{/it} by pornography

pt: {sc}corrupt{/sc} implies loss of soundness, purity, or integrity.

pt.t: the belief that bureaucratese {it}corrupts{/it} the language

pt: {sc}debauch{/sc} implies a debasing through sensual indulgence.

pt.t: the long stay on a tropical isle had {it}debauched{/it} the ship's crew

pt: {sc}pervert{/sc} implies a twisting or distorting from what is natural or normal.

pt.t: {it}perverted{/it} the original goals of the institute

et: Middle English, from Latin {it}corruptus{/it}, past participle of {it}corrumpere{/it}, from {it}com-{/it} + {it}rumpere{/it} to break {ma}{mat|reave|}{/ma}
shortdef: to change from good to bad in morals, manners, or actions; also : bribe
to degrade with unsound principles or moral values
